Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: The Doctoral Scholars in Engineering (DSiE) project at Morgan State University has initiated a community of doctoral scholars in engineering that is focused on academic achievement and career preparation The objectives of this project are to: 1) increase access to the doctorate, especially for underrepresented minority students; 2) improve doctoral degree completion and time to degree by relieving scholars of the need for off-campus employment; 3) improve support programs for doctoral students in the School of Engineering; and 4) increase the preparation and placement of doctoral students in academic and research careers. This project is producing graduates who are well grounded in their disciplines and well prepared for career success. The project strategies are designed to improve doctoral student retention and graduation rates, thereby contributing to an increased engineering work force.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Doctoral Scholars in Engineering (DSiE) project at Morgan State University initiated a community of doctoral scholars in engineering that is focused on academic achievement and career preparation The objectives of this project were to: 1) increase access to the doctorate, especially for underrepresented minority students; 2) improve doctoral degree completion and time to degree by relieving scholars of the need for off-campus employment; 3) improve support programs for doctoral students in the School of Engineering; and 4) increase the preparation and placement of doctoral students in academic and research careers.

The project activities consisted of (i) student recruitment and selection ii) academic preparation and development; (iii) industrial community outreach and mentoring. Participants were provided with opportunities such as seminars and workshops to enhance their preparation to complete their dissertation and be well positioned for their careers. These evidence-based activities reviewed time management, goal setting, expectations of doctoral students, managing the dissertation process and players, and introduced dissertation tools. Participants also received academic and career mentoring.

This project supported 28 students over a six-year period, producing graduates who are well grounded in their disciplines and well prepared for career success. The project strategies were designed to improve doctoral student retention and graduation rates, thereby contributing to an increased engineering work force.

 


Last Modified: 10/29/2019
Modified by: Jumoke O Ladeji-Osias

The project activities consisted of (i) student recruitment and selection ii) academic preparation and development; (iii) industrial community outreach and mentoring. Participants were provided with opportunities such as seminars and workshops to enhance their preparation to complete their dissertation and be well positioned for their careers. These evidence-based activities reviewed time management, goal setting, expectations of doctoral students, managing the dissertation process and players, and introduced dissertation tools. Participants also received academic and career mentoring. This project supported 28 students over a six-year period, producing graduates who are well grounded in their disciplines and well prepared for career success.
